question_text: A 31-year-old man is evaluated for a 3-week illness consisting of fever, dyspnea, and dry cough. He has risk factors for HIV infection.Frontal chest radiograph is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: This patient most likely has Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (Option D). The posterior-anterior chest radiograph shows diffuse bilateral airspace disease, characterized by ground-glass changes and minute nodules, with possible formation of small cysts. The infiltrates are predominantly in the middle lung zones. In a patient with AIDS who has a CD4 cell count less than 200/Î¼L, these findings suggest P. jirovecii pneumonia; however, this pneumonia can present with a wide range of radiographic findings, including lobar infiltrates, pneumothoraces, and normal images. A normal chest radiograph does not exclude the diagnosis; when clinically indicated, chest CT is more sensitive, demonstrating patchy ground-glass opacities. Diagnosis can be confirmed by identification of stains of the organism in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. The Gomori methenamine stain of the sputum shows the pneumocystis organism.
